item.title: China Found World’s Pain Point on Trade — and Will Use It Again
item.description: For months Donald Trump pushed tariffs and trade restrictions on China to unprecedented levels, part of a strategy to force Xi Jinping into talks the US president expected would help cut the trade deficit and boost American manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Alberto Nardelli, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: NdFeB alloy strip at the Australia Strategic Materials Ltd.'s Korean Metals Plant, in the Ochang Foreign Investment Zone, in Cheongju, South Korea, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025.

item.title: Investor Rush for India Exposure Revs Up Block Deals, IPOs
item.description: India’s market for share sales is warming up after a several dull months, as companies and shareholders cash in on a buoyant stock market.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

item.title: Airbus Sees Global Aircraft Fleet Doubling by 2044, Led by India
item.description: Airbus SE predicted the global commercial aircraft fleet will double in size to almost 50,000 planes over the next 20 years, spurred by rapid growth in markets like India, where a rising middle class increasingly takes to air travel.
item.dc:creator: Siddharth Vikram Philip

item.title: With Friends Like Brazil, OPEC+ Doesn’t Need Enemies
item.description: It’s clear that a boom is following the bust, and the timing couldn’t be worse for the Saudi-led oil cartel.
item.dc:creator: Javier Blas

item.title: Toho Titanium Shares Jump as JX Metals Mulls Unwinding
item.description: Toho Titanium Co. shares surged after parent JX Advanced Metals Corp. said it’s considering ways to unwind the listing of the titanium unit as Japan’s complex system of subsidiaries comes under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Yasutaka Tamura

item.title: Dollar, Stock Futures Drop on Trump Tariff Threat: Markets Wrap
item.description: US equity-index futures fell along with the dollar after President Donald Trump said he will set unilateral tariff rates within two weeks, dialing up trade tensions once again. Haven assets such as Treasuries and gold rose.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: Morning commuters in the Marunouchi district of Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Sept. 3, 2024. Japan’s unemployment rate rose to 2.7 percent in July from the prior month at 2.5 percent, according to the government’s statistics bureau in Tokyo. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Pares Mideast-Driven Surge as Trade Tensions Flare Up Again
item.description: Oil edged lower — after jumping more than 4% on Wednesday — as traders tracked tensions in the Middle East and the latest moves in US trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck, Sarah Chen

item.title: China Gets First Private Builder Dollar Bond Offering Since 2023
item.description: Seazen Group Ltd., one of the few major private-sector Chinese developers yet to default, started marketing a dollar bond that would be the first of its kind in more than two years.
item.dc:creator: Ameya Karve, Jackie Cai, Qingqi She, Emma Dong

item.title: China’s Cheap Funding Breathes Life Into Leveraged Bond Trades
item.description: China’s efforts to support the economy by keeping funding costs low are increasing lending among banks, in a sign they may be borrowing cheaply to buy bonds for a profit.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv

item.title: JSW Cement Is Said to Eye Mumbai IPO as Roadshow Begins
item.description: JSW Cement Ltd. has kicked off a roadshow for its planned initial public offering that could take place in Mumbai as soon as next month, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Sachdev, Baiju Kalesh

media:content.media:description: Advertisements for JSW Steel Ltd., left, and JSW Cement Ltd. in Dolvi, Maharashtra. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Mid-Cap Stocks to Thrive on AI Boom, Ox Capital Says
item.description: Chinese mid-cap stocks will be the next winners as companies take advantage of advancements in artificial intelligence, according to a fund manager at Ox Capital Management Pty Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Carmeli Argana, Abhishek Vishnoi

media:content.media:description: Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP/ Getty Images Photographer: WANG ZHAO/AFP

item.title: Japan Complains After Chinese Fighter Jet Buzzes Patrol Plane
item.description: Tokyo has complained to Beijing after a Chinese fighter jet tailed a Japanese patrol aircraft over the weekend, flying as close as 45 meters from the aircraft, according to Japan’s Defense Ministry.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: A J-15T jet in 2024. Photographer: CFOTO/CFOTO

item.title: Ivanhoe Cuts Copper Guidance as Part of Flooded Mine Reopens
item.description: Ivanhoe Mines Ltd. slashed its output guidance for this year — and withdrew an estimate for 2026 — after restarting underground operations in part of its flood-hit copper mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood, Martin Ritchie

media:content.media:description: This April 26, 2018 general view shows the mining site of Kamoa Kakula, exploited by Kamoa Holding (Ivanhoe Mines, Zijin Mining Group, together with the DRC government), in Kamoa, 25km from Kolwezi. - The mining site is one of the largest unexploited copper field in the world, and stands on the site of the battles for Kolwezi, in May 1978 during the second Shaba War where French and Belgian paratroopers fought agains the Katanga rebels. On May 19, 1978, French soldiers parachuted into the Democratic Republic of Congo town of Kolwezi to rescue hundreds of Europeans held by rebels who had already massacred several. (Photo by CAROLINE THIRION / AFP) (Photo credit should read CAROLINE THIRION/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Foreign Investors Pour Into South Korean Bonds at Record Pace
item.description: Foreign investors accelerated purchases of South Korean bonds at a record pace in May, highlighting growing appetite for the asset class in the run-up to the presidential election and ahead of the addition to a major global index.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom

media:content.media:description: Commercial and residential buildings seen from the rooftop of the Lotte Corp. World Tower at sunset in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. South Korea is also set to report on trade data Friday, one of the earliest looks into how global demand was holding up in November. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: CDPQ Looks to Trim US Assets as CEO Worries About Stagflation
item.description: The head of Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec said it’s time for the fund to scale back on US investments after years of growth and great returns.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

item.title: New World Bondholders Want More Disclosure on Financing Plans
item.description: New World Development Co. bondholders are growing frustrated with the level of financial disclosure by the cash-strapped developer as it prioritizes communication with banks during critical loan talks.
item.dc:creator: Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu, Apple Ka Ying Li

item.title: 'Still Quite Constructive' on Chinese Stocks in Second Half of 2025: JPM Private Bank
item.description: Julia Wang of JPMorgan Private Bank says the firm is "still quite constructive" on Chinese stocks for the second half of 2025. She speaks on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Korean Stock Hedges Cheapen With $3.2 Billion of Bullish Bets
item.description: South Korea’s presidential election last week has sparked the biggest equity surge in more than four years. Options traders are betting there’s more to come.
item.dc:creator: Daedo Kim, Sangmi Cha

item.title: Chinese Stocks’ Premium Over Hong Kong Peers Drops to 5-Year Low
item.description: The premium that Chinese stocks command over their Hong Kong-traded peers has narrowed to a five-year low, suggesting that some investors may look to snap up onshore stocks that have become cheaper.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, April Ma

item.title: Dollar Extends Its Slide as US Tariff Concerns Pick Up Again
item.description: The dollar extended its decline versus major peers as worries over US tariffs increased after President Donald Trump said he would notify trading partners soon of unilateral levy rates.
item.dc:creator: David Finnerty

item.title: Global Funds Return But Largest India-Focused ETF in US Continues to See Outflows
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Citadel Securities Hires Millennium’s Narang for Asia COO Team
item.description: Ken Griffin’s market-making giant Citadel Securities LLC has hired Mayank Narang for its Asia chief operating officer team amid expansion in the region, said a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Bei Hu

item.title: Trump Says Again He’ll Set Unilateral Tariffs in Two Weeks
item.description: US President Donald Trump says he intends to send letters to trading partners in the next one to two weeks setting unilateral tariff rates, ahead of a July 9 deadline to reimpose higher duties on dozens of economies. He was speaking at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington where he was attending a performance. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump: China Will Ship Rare Earths in ‘Done’ Trade Deal
item.description: US President Donald Trump says a trade framework with China has been completed, with Beijing supplying rare earths and magnets and the US allowing Chinese students into its colleges and universities. Bloomberg's Stephen Engle breaks down Trump's latest statements. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Likely to Ditch Low-Grade Coal From Indonesia Due to Glut
item.description: China is likely to cut imports of the lowest grades of coal as a glut of the fuel makes the trade uneconomic and the government tightens up on carbon emissions.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Kathy Chen

media:content.media:description: Photo credit should read CHU BAORUI / Feature China/Future Publishing via Getty Images)

item.title: Couche-Tard Sees ‘Clear Path’ to Seven & i Deal With US Stores Divestment
item.description: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. said that it sees several clear paths to complete a takeover of Seven & i Holdings Co., the strongest signal of confidence it’s sent so far on the controversial buyout that would be the biggest-ever foreign acquisition of a Japanese company.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

item.title: Oaktree’s Marks Says Trump Values Unpredictability, Be Cautious
item.description: Oaktree Capital Management LP co-founder Howard Marks said investors should expect uncertainty to endure under US President Donald Trump and relatively high valuations in global markets require a cautious stance.
item.dc:creator: Adam Haigh

item.title: Gold Advances on Middle East Tensions and Trump’s Tariff Pledge
item.description: Gold gained for a second day on increased tensions in the Middle East, with its haven status also supported by President Donald Trump’s comments that he will inform trading partners on tariff rates within two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Funds Pile Into Southeast Asian Bonds Even at Record Low Yields
item.description: Investors are making a beeline for Southeast Asian sovereign bonds despite their record low yields amid a shift away from US assets and on bets for further interest-rate cuts in the region.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Japan Credit Sales See Busiest June in Years as Buyers Seek Risk
item.description: Japanese borrowers have already sold more corporate bonds than they have for any June in four years, and the month isn’t even halfway through.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga
